segments.text: elevated bed when the revolution started and they abandoned the project.
I don't know what the revolution would have properly if they had had the railroad.
That's why they didn't have communications to move the troops.
Of course, the revolution had to come and they had to win, but it would have lasted longer.
I mean, it wouldn't have lasted as long.
No, it would have lasted longer if they had built the Laredo because the federal troops would have had access to these sections.
Oh, I see, to the border area.
Well, just how important was this region up and down the border, say, from Laredo south?
Was it important to the revolution?
Well, they had to take it because they couldn't get the supplies.
Once they got to the border town, they couldn't get supplies.
I see.
The United States was in favor of the revolution, with supplies and arms.
So that's why places like Nuevo Laredo and Guerrero and all these places were important.
Were there ever any battles in Guerrero?
No, no, no.
Because they didn't have an important motto.
The people left, the revolutionaries came, they ransacked the town.
I went to, after we left, a few days later, I went to Guerrero again with another cousin of mine to see what was, bring some more stuff.
And we find the doors broken and all the rooms empty, empty, everything.
Of your home, all your furniture and everything?
Furniture and clothing and everything.
Oh, and this is after you'd come across the river.
Yes, in April 1913, when we moved to Zapata.
A few days later, I went back to Guerrero.
My father sent me with another cousin in Bahia.
by horse carriage to see what we could salvage.
We didn't find anything.
And there had been...
This is my other sister.
My sister.
One of the six.
One of the six sisters.
How old are you?
I'm married to no one.
This is my daughter.
She's from California.
She's living in California.
And this is my daughter.
And this is my mother.
And what they're teaching me, telling me that I have to learn and remember again the weather here.
It gets rather pleasant in the morning.
Yes, that's what I thought.
I'm glad to see you.
I'm going.
I'm going to visit.
For the Hawaiian visitors, summer friends, my sister.
Well, that's all.
But do you like a cup of tea, a cup of coffee?
Anything?
A cup of coffee would be very nice.
to have a conference with him.
And then one of the times he told one of the reporters, will it be possible that Francisco Madero will start a revolution?
He says, any fool can start a revolution.
It will take a genius to finish.
And then another thing he said,
Unfortunately, Mexican people are so far from God and so close to the United States,
Well, I'd like for you to tell me a little bit more about really a completely different subject, and that is the building of Falcon Dam and the refugees.
You really have another set of refugees when the floodwaters covered Guerrero, don't you?
Yeah, they covered a raw deal, the poor people.
because they just abandoned them.
The Mexican government did?
No, the American side.
The American side?
There was nothing on the Mexican side.
Oh, I thought Guerrero was.
No, Guerrero.
They compensated the owners of the houses in Guerrero and built houses for them on the new Guerrero.
Oh, the Mexican government did that?
Yes, on the Mexican side.
But on the American side, the ranches and everything, they got the Rodil.
They compensated them in a very poor way.
Well, tell me about it.
How did it all come about?
Politics, I guess.
They didn't have stronger politicians to speak for them.
Well, how did the dam come about?
How did all of this happen?
People in the valley, they needed some more water because they were extracting water from the Rio Grande for the valley, or so many, say, dozen cities.
Very well developed.
On the Mexican side, it was underdeveloped.
So Mexico and the United States agreed to build that dam so that they could cut enough water to irrigate both the American side and create an irrigation system on the Mexican side.
And then it was agreed on a 60-40% basis.
The United States would get 60% and the rest was 40%.
It took about 3 or 4 years to build it.
It cost about 40 or 50 million dollars.
They did a good job.
And then on the Mexican side they built a hydroelectric plant too.
to serve Guerrero.
I think they bring the power to Nueva Guerrero.
You say the Mexican government built a whole new town.
Yes, they compensated them enough to build new houses in the new Guerrero.
Modern houses are bricks or prefabricated houses.
And did they build them, you know, a new church and school and this sort of thing?
Yes, a church and a municipal city hall.
They moved a statue of Benito Juarez and a clock.
They called it a clock.
Of course, it's out of fix.
That clock was purchased in France.
They had it in the city hall in the old Guerrero.
It was a very exact clock.
Well, how did the people feel?
Were they satisfied with moving?
They had opportunities to plant in the old garage.
They didn't have pumps or anything to lift the water for irrigation.
And then they have this tourist trade and the fishing industry.
And then the transportation.
The new garage is a transportation center.
So it's really done pretty, those people have done pretty well.
And then they have this irrigation system below the river, down to Matamoros.
But you say on the United States side it wasn't that way.
Because it was just the ranch owners, it was nothing being a big deal.
Just a few ranchers that had their little houses there.
I don't think they got proper indemnization for it.
That's the general word.
When President Eisenhower came to inaugurate the dam, the people were living in tents near Falcon.
She saw them there in tents.
Well, what about Nuzapata?
Were the people given houses or anything?
I think...
I don't know.
They got some sort of compensation.
Some sort of compensation.
But not as much as on the Mexican side.
No, I don't know the details, but they are satisfied.
And then the talk has grown.
It has grown.
And then they talk about highways from here to Zapata, and then from Zapata to Quebronville, from Zapata down to the valley.
Has life changed a lot in New Zapata?
Modernized now.
There are many fishing industries, motels.
Do you think people are as satisfied as they were before?
People in Zapata, are they as satisfied?
Certainly, better than they were before.
Because Zapata was a little sleepy town too.
There were not good communications.
But back when it was actually happening, when the lands were being flooded, were you ever down there?
Back when the lands were being flooded, what was it like?
When the water was building up behind the dam?
Well, it didn't affect the water very much.
Just on the creeks, the water just went there.
Not much.
It didn't reclaim many lands, of course.
The federal government retained title to certain distance from the highest level of the water to the inland.
A strip of land is owned by the government, and the government in times allowed them to graze their cattle.
So they eventually got involved.
Then they discovered this livestock industry is very profitable in oil, oil production.
That's nature.
In deserts they have oil, because nature compensates one thing for the other.
Do you still have relatives in Guerrero?
All my uncles and aunts and everything, they are dead.
They're dead.
Did their children come to the States, or did they stay there?
They lived there, but we have lost track of them.
Oh, I see.
So they're there, but you just don't visit very much.
Our closest relative was my uncle.
He moved here to Laredo and died here.
Did he bring a family, too?
Sure, there could have been family.

he brought what his wife and his wife and children how many children did he have you see how destiny works my uncle had a little ranch where this seven sisters land do you know about that no it's an old section of seven sisters because he owned a ranch there soledad was named and back in 1905 or 19 there was 1900
He wanted, he had his eyes toward Mexico.
And see, he engaged in surveillance and started to survey the landscape and found that there were many lands that didn't have any owners.
Then he reported that to Mexico City as a reward.
They needed a big chunk of land, about 18 or 20,000 acres.
Then, so he sold it right here.
In the United States.
Yes, and then went to there and engaged in politics.
In the meantime, that land, he got millions now.
If he had stayed here, he would have been a millionaire.
So he had had a ranch.
Was it a ranch he inherited?
He owned a ranch here.
Had he inherited it or how did he get it?
He bought it.
And he lived in Guerrero, but he bought a ranch.
No, he lived in the ranch and then... Oh, he lived in the United States.
I see.
And then from time to time, they would go to Guerrero for two or three months to have the children, then come back to the ranch.
But it was that misguided loyalty, I call it.
Misguided loyalty.
Because in about 1907, he went back to live in Guerrero and bought a big land and then engaged in politics.
And since he was a conservative, he was one of the group of people that controlled the town, the political life of the town.
And then became mayor.
One night in September 1912,
We were celebrating the independence.
And then after midnight, we lived across the street.
We heard a big explosion across from us.
And then immediately another big explosion.
And then two or three minutes later, another explosion fired away.
Then later on we found that these revolutionaries had put two bombs in their house.
One on the big gate that all those houses had to put the carriage in.
They put one there and another one in another door.
It was a two-story house.
But the night was warm.
They decided instead of sleeping upstairs, they went to the yard and sleep there.
That saved them because they destroyed the second story and blew it up.
He would have killed them.
This was your uncle's family?
My uncle.
He was the mayor.
And the other one was another political chief.
They put it on the door, on the gate, but it did some damage, but it didn't do anything to the man, a man named Ramirez.
That was one thing.
And then that was in September 1912.
Then in 1913 is when Madero was killed and Huerta took power.
A few days before April, they attacked the town.
And my uncle called policemen and certain individuals armed on the roofs of the houses to defend the government in case of attack.
Well, they came and attacked.
And these fellows that he could pay just quit.
They got cold feet.
They stay flat and didn't do anything.
So my uncle's sons,
And my father had to go to the ropes and repel the attackers, repel them.
Now, this uncle was your father's brother?
My father's brother.
And what was his name?
Sinesio.
Sinesio Gutierrez.
So my children, they cut the bones and they'd chop bones.
They came in a horseback.
They found that they could not take it.
They went to assassinate my uncle.
Did you get on the roof with a gun too?
No, no, I was very young then.
I went with my mother into the room.
We had a big house, 350, so we were safe there.
So it lasted about half an hour or so.
They could not take it and left.
And then they knew who these men that put those bombs were.
They were part of the revolutionaries.
And my uncle asked help from the governor of Tamaulipas to send in troops or somebody.
They could not send, so decided to quit.
Then at night, they left by foot, went from Guerrero to a little ranch about a few miles south of Zapata.
Then in the morning we found that my father wasn't there, my uncle wasn't there.
Then my aunt told them, no, they are safe already on the American side.
Now we are going to Zapata now.
We can go.
But we cannot take anything just because we have arms.
Did you leave the very next day or was it the next morning?
The very next morning.
It's two miles from, of course it took us three hours to get there by carriage.
It wasn't really that far then.
No, it wasn't that far, but by carriage it took longer to travel two miles.
Well, your uncle then, did he ever get any land on the United States side after you moved here?
Your uncle, what did he do after he got to the States to make a living?
Did he lose his land in Mexico?
No.
At that time the revolution was about over and he, of course the land was, at that time livestock was worth about $30 per head.
During the revolution,
the hide were very valuable.
So the revolution would slaughter the livestock just to reclaim the hide and ship it to the United States.
So they stole all his cattle.
Oh, I see.
Then when things became settled, he leased the land, the subsoil, to one of these American companies.
They paid him very good rental.
Very good rental.
And then, when the revolution ended, he took over the ranch again.
This is his ranch in Mexico?
In Mexico, yes.
Did he move back to Mexico?
He stayed here, but he...
But he managed, his children managed the ranch.
There's another incident during the...
December 1913, 1913, when we moved back here, my uncle sent his family to the south and he and the trio of his children remained in Nuevo Laredo because they organized, the Guatagoros organized the
a group of armed men called the Defensa Social, Social Defense, and they recruited all these civilians to bear arms, and they are the ones who helped to defend the city.
My uncle remained there, so.
No.
Yes, my uncle moved here, the children stayed there, that was on December.
Now, on April, he moved back to Nuevo Laredo.
And then, when the government troops burned the town and left the city, they took my uncle and his boys with them.
Because they had no choice.
They had to go with them.
So they went off with the government troops.
That was the troops of Huerta, Victoriana Huerta.
And they went as far as Villaldana.
Yes, I know where Villaldana is.
So he returned, but I don't know if I heard back or something.
How did he get away then from the government troops?
Did they just...
When everything disbanded, the government troops went to another route and Pancho Villa met them.
And then they had a battle and won the battle and killed the general that had defended Nuevo Laredo.
It was General Guardiola.
He was a colonel and they made him general.
They killed him there.
My uncle and his son came by horseback and they were intercepted by the Carranza troops and brought to Nuevo Laredo as prisoners.
Then they released the boys.
And what kept him, they said that they were going to execute him.
But finally they started to pull strings and then finally they managed to, they captured him in San Ignacio.
That's where they captured him, in San Ignacio.
They were about to cross when they caught him.
So they relieved the boys and kept my uncle.
And then finally they got to,
got the concession to take him to Matamoros to try him there.
They took him by carriage.
Took him to Matamoros.
From Matamoros, they took him to Monterrey.
Monterrey, they got him to pay him about 45,000 pesos in Mexican currency.
He had money in the banks in Monterrey.
He paid that money.
And they released him, and then he went by way of Eagle Pass, and then to Laredo.
to Laredo and then from Laredo moved to Eagle Pass again.

He wanted to stay away from all this and then lived in Eagle Pass for some time until the revolution ended and come here and then lease the subsoil to the American company and then got good money for rentals.
And then the livestock business, he was a good businessman.
But he apparently never wanted to go back to Mexico after.
After Guarno, he stayed here.
He managed, his boys, sons managed the ranch.
Well, he was very lucky not to be killed, wasn't he?
That's right, because they pulled the strings and then moved him to Monterey.
This Pan American Highway crosses the ranch in the middle.
It's about 40 miles from here.
where the ranch was divided into parts.
Between his sons?
His children.
His children now have it.
It was about 20,000 acres.
Now where do his children live?
Well, some of them, there remain only one, two,
Three.
Three children, grown-ups already.
All the others, I guess there were eight in the family.
All the other men have died.
And then there are about three women that are already married and live here in Laredo.
So now the land belongs to the grandchildren.
No, to his own children.
To his own children.
And then they sold it to somebody else.
Oh, I see.
It has been divided for them.
But what I say is that he made a big mistake in selling this land here out of loyalty to go to Mexico.
You think he felt like it just wasn't right to own land in the United States or what?
No, no.
He want to go to Mexico.
I see.
And then he got to sell the land here.
Well, how had he happened to move up here in the first place?
That's why I say Guerrero has had a big influence.
People from Guerrero owned ranches here.
I see.
And had owned ranches.
Many old-timers from Laredo came from Guerrero and owned ranches here.
I see.
And they'd owned ranches here since way back... Way back.
More than 200 years ago.
I see.
So they... Let me tell you that priest, uncle or great-granddaughter, was the only one surveying all this.
What did they call this land?
They divided from the river so much frontage.
I don't know how many, five or ten thousand
varas, and then they got 10,000 varas back.
Everyone, all the lands, the grants, had access to the river.
And then later on had been subdivided.
And then that priest is the one who made all these surveys.
Who surveyed all the porciones?
Porciones.
Porciones.
So most of these porciones were owned by people who lived in Guerrero.
And here in Laredo too, the grants by that Captain Sanchez that founded Laredo.
That's a funny story about Captain Sanchez.
Many people claim that they are descendants of Sanchez.
It happened that Sanchez never married.
Well, did he have children?
That's what I say.
He had many children, but he never married.
They are proud to be the sons of God.
He never married.
Oh, well.
You can verify that from certain people.
How did he marry?
He never married.
But he was a good man.
He had a lot of kids.
That's very interesting.
I knew he had children, but I didn't know he'd never married.
Were his children just by one wife, or did he just have children all over the place?
Several women.
Very interesting man.
He was a fairly wealthy man, wasn't he, Captain Sanchez?
Well, in that time wealth was measured by land and livestock.
Cows, horses, goats, that's how the wealth was measured.
Where did they sell their stock back in those days?
The livestock, how did they sell it?
They shipped it to San Antonio by land and then from San Antonio down to Ecuador.
And then they had goats here.
Did they ever move it south, further south?
No, not to Mexico.
Mexico didn't need them.
They produced enough.
But at that time a coal steer was worth $30.
And they used to kill them just to salvage the skin, the hide.
Well, it's changed a little bit now, hasn't it?
No, the steak is worth it.
Thirty dollars?
Well, not quite that much, but steak for a family is about...
It's big enough.
They are going to, for stealing steaks from the supermarket.
Oh, are they?
Well, what about meat prices in Mexico now?
Have they gone up?
Meat is scarce in Mexico.
You see, when we came here, meat was nine cents a pound.
Very cheap.
But there were no jobs or anything.
There were no automobiles.
Just these carriages, course carriages.
Then they had an electric streetcar that went to the cemetery.
It crossed the street from the east to west and then to the cemetery.
So things have changed quite a bit.
Life has changed.
Well, how do you feel?
Are you glad that the revolution came and you came here?
I said, are you glad that the revolution happened and you ended up coming to this side?
For me, it has been a good life.
Good life.
Well, I thank you very much.
